Properties: Seed (after stir-frying): fragrant; slightly sweet; bland.
Bud: tasteless at first, then acrid, numbing, and toxic; bad odor.
Maladies Treated: Pain caused by uterus not getting back in place.
Dosage:
Seeds: 12–18 g. Used in decoction, pill, or powder.
Buds: 3–6 g. Used in decoction.
Bud paste: daily dosage 0.5 cc, taken in 2 or 3 servings; for asthma and insomnia.
Samples of Formulae:
Bud paste (for asthma and insomnia):
Preparation: Chop buds 500 g into fine particles; add water 1000 cc; simmer; strain; then simmer the filtrate until 30 cc remain to form a paste.
Source: Yang Teem Hua.
Contraindications:
Do not overdose.
Chronic usage can cause amotivational syndrome (aimlessness and un-communication) and incoherent speech.
Withdrawal symptoms can include anorexia, insomnia, anxiety, and depression.
Smoking during pregnancy may cause miscarriage or underweight fetus.
Adverse reactions can include dysphoria, tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension/low blood pressure, and may abruptly develop into latent schizophrenia.
Long-term use may cause weight gain.

Name: chai hu
Biological: Bupleurum scorzonerifolium Willd. (紅柴胡，南柴胡，細柴胡，軟柴胡)
Other name: chun chai hu (spring chai hu) 春柴胡
Bupleurum chinense: bei chai hu (northern chai hu 北柴胡), ying chai hu (hard chai hu 硬柴胡)
Bupleurum scorzonerifolium: nan chai hu (southern chai hu 南柴胡), xi chai hu (thin chai hu 細柴胡), ruan chai hu (soft chai hu 軟柴胡)

Geography: Bupleurum chinense DC. (north chai hu) is mainly produced in Liaoning, Gansu, Hebei, Henan.
Bupleurum scorzonerifolium Willd. (south chai hu / xi chai hu / ruan chai hu) is mainly produced in Hubei, Jiangsu, Sichuan.
Maladies Treated: qi stagnation with fullness in chest and rib cage
Medical Function: effects on heart and blood vessels
diuretic effect: small amount improves urination; large amount does not have this effect
fried chai hu: after stir-frying, reduces the herb's cold nature and enhances the effect of lifting clear yang
wine-treated chai hu (酒柴胡): enhances blood circulation and enhances yang function
vinegar stir-fried chai hu (醋炒柴胡): directs action to the liver channel; enhances soothing the liver and harmonizing the blood; arrests pain
Samples of Formulae:
Xiao Chai Hu Tang (小柴胡湯).

Chai Hu Gui Zhi Gan Jiang Tang (柴胡桂枝乾薑湯).

Formula for Eye Viral Infection (眼睛病毒感染).

Fried chai hu (炒柴胡): Place chai hu slices in a frying pan and dry-fry to slightly charred. Aged wine or wheat bran can be added for stir-frying. After frying, the herb is less cold in nature and enhances the effect of lifting clear yang when taken. Wine-treated chai hu (酒柴胡) enhances blood circulation and yang function.

Vinegar stir-fried chai hu (醋炒柴胡; cu chao chai hu): Mix chai hu slices evenly with rice vinegar (100 kg chai hu to 10 kg rice vinegar), let sit briefly, then place in a pot and gently stir-fry over low heat until slight charring appears; spread out to dry before storage. After processing, it especially enters the liver channel and enhances soothing the liver and harmonizing the blood, and stops pain.

Soft shell turtle blood chai hu (鱉血柴胡): Evenly mix chai hu slices with soft shell turtle blood and yellow rice wine (per 1 kg chai hu, use 100 g turtle blood and 150 g yellow rice wine diluted and mixed with chai hu), then stir-fry over low heat until dry; remove, spread out to cool, and store. After processing, it enhances the nourishing-yin antipyretic action; nourishes yin and clears heat; eliminates malaria; disperses lumps; especially suitable for liver stagnation with yin deficiency, and appropriate for bone-steaming tidal fever (骨蒸勞熱).

See list of other chai hu formulae (其他柴胡方劑).
Contraindications:
Mildly toxic. Not for use in cases of yin deficiency cough or headache due to ascending liver fire.

Overdose may cause headache, dizziness, vomiting, tremors, gastroenteritis, and pathogenic erections.

There were reported cases of mortality from broncho-interstitial pneumonia suspected to be caused by combined use of chai hu formulae and interferon (有將柴胡製劑與干擾素併用，引發間質性肺炎而死亡的案例).

Large dosages and/or long-term usage may be toxic to the kidneys (大劑量或長期服用可能對腎臟有毒).
Notes: Ruan chai hu (軟柴胡; soft chai hu): After harvesting the above-ground stems and leaves, remove the old stalks, sun-dry, and tie into bundles; this product is sold as ruan chai hu (also called miao chai hu 苗柴胡).

Fried chai hu: put chai hu pieces in frying pan and fry to slightly charred. Aged wine or wheat bran can also be added for the stir-frying. After stir frying, the characteristics of the herb will be not be so cold and can enhance the yang characteristics of the body when taken. Jiu chai hu (wine treated chai hu) can enhance blood circulation, and enhance yang function.

Cu chao chai hu (vinegar stir fried chai hu): Mix chai hu slicess with vinegar (chai hu 100 kg to 10 kg), let sit for a short time, and set the pot and the mixture on the stove and gently stir-fry until slightly charred. Spread out to dry. After this process, cu chai hu is known for entering the liver channel and also in arresting pain.

Soft shell turtle blood chai hu: Evenly mix chai hu slices with soft shell turtle blood and rice wine (100 Kg of turtle blood and 150 Kg of rice wine). Stir. Pan fry till dry. Take out and spread out to air cool. After this process, the function of the herb is enhanced in its antipyretic effect in nourishing yin and removing heat, ridding of malaria, removing lumps, especially effective for liver stagnation with yin deficient, particularly appropriate gu zhen lao re condition.

Ruan chai hu (soft chai hu): after harvesting the above ground stems and leaves, removing the old stalks, dry, tie into bundle, it is sold as ruan chai hu (soft Bupleurum) also call miao chai hu (sprout Bupleurum).
 

炒柴胡： 以柴胡片於鍋中清炒至微焦為度，亦可加陳酒或麩皮拌炒，炒後可避其涼性，而增升舉清陽之效。 酒柴胡增強活血，升陽通經作用。

醋炒柴胡： 取柴胡片，用米醋拌勻(柴胡100公斤用米醋10公斤)，稍悶，置鍋內用文火炒至略見焦斑時，取出攤開晾干收貯。經製後獨入肝經 ，增強舒肝和血、止痛之功。

鱉血柴胡： 取柴胡片用鱉血和黃酒拌勻(每公斤柴胡，用鱉血100克與黃酒150克和勻稀釋後拌柴胡)，入鍋內用文火炒干。取出攤晾收貯，炮 制後增強其滋陽退熱作用，能養陰制瘧，消痞塊，對肝郁而陰虧者尤宜應用，適用於骨蒸勞熱等症。

軟柴胡：收割地上莖葉，去掉老莖稈，晒乾，捆扎成把，即為軟柴胡（苗柴胡）

Name: hai tong pi
海桐皮
Biological: Erythrina variegata L. var. orientalis (L.) MERR.
Common: English: coral bean bark, erythrina bark

Maladies Treated: Bark: chronic and cold type of rheumatoid arthritis (from formula context)
Bark: fungal infection of skin (from formula context)
Dosage: 6 to 12 g. Use appropriate amount for external application.
Samples of Formulae:
For chronic and cold type of rheumatoid arthritis: Composition: hai tong pi (Erythrina bark), xu duan (Teasel root), du zhong (Eucommia bark), dang gui (Angelica sinensis root), wu jia pi (Acanthopanax bark). Preparation: Make into decoction. Use as tea. Indication: chronic and cold type of rheumatoid arthritis.
For fungal infection of skin: Composition: hai tong pi (Erythrina bark), di fu zi (Kochia fruit), she zhuang zi (Cnidium seed), huang bai (Phellodendron bark). Preparation: Make into decoction. Use as tea. Indication: fungal infection of skin.
Contraindications: Not to use in cases of blood deficiency (血虛).
Original Text:
hai tong pi, Complementary and Alternative Healing University

Name: huo xiang
Common: English: agastache; patchouli; pogostemon (P. cablin); Korean mint

Maladies Treated: Vomiting and diarrhea due to spleen deficiency with stomach cold (pixu, wei han)
Chest or abdomen tightness due to pixu (spleen deficient)
Dosage:
5 to 10 g.
Fresh herb: 10 to 20 g.
Do not boil too long or the effective ingredients of essential oil may be lost.
Samples of Formulae:
See pregnancy nausea formula #2.
huo xiang zheng qi san 藿香正氣散.
Contraindications: Contraindicated in yinxu (yin deficiency) with heat and in Stomach fire.
Research: The decoction of huo xiang possesses antibiotic effect in vitro on many pathogenic fungi and leptospirosis.
